Authors:
Sandra I.R. Videira, Johannes (Ewald) Zacharias Groenewald,
Gerard JM Verkley, Uwe Braun, Pedro W. Crous
Title: The rise of Ramularia from the Mycosphaerella labyrinth
Keywords:
cercosporoid, cryptic species, multigene, nomenclature,
phylogeny
Abstract:
Mycosphaerella s. lat. is one of the largest genera of
Ascomycetes and includes numerous important plant pathogens. While the
morphology of the sexual morph is relatively uniform across the
Mycosphaerellaceae, the morphology of the associated asexual genera is
highly diverse. The type species, M. punctiformis, has been epitypified
and its asexual morph described as Ramularia endophylla, and the
conservation of R. endophylla is proposed in this study. In light of
recent changes to the International Code of Nomenclature for Algae,
Fungi and Plants, the name Ramularia takes precedence over
Mycosphaerella since it is older, is well circumscribed and has recently
been monographed. Ramularia endophylla is an endophytic fungus usually
associated with broad-leaved trees and is distributed worldwide. Several
strains of R. endophylla were found to be heterogeneous with regard to
the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of the nuclear ribosomal
DNA. In this study we aimed to resolve this species-complex by applying
a polyphasic approach involving morphology and multi-gene phylogeny.
Eleven partial genes were targeted for amplification and sequencing for
a total of 81 isolates representing R. endophylla s. lat. and 32
isolates representing 11 Ramularia species that were previously linked
to a Mycosphaerella sexual morph in literature. A Bayesian phylogenetic
analysis, as well as a parsimony analysis, was performed on a combined
five-locus dataset and the resulting trees showed significant support
for three species within the complex, including the previously described
R. endophylla and R. vizellae, and one novel species, R. unterseheri. A
parsimony analysis was also separately performed with mating-type gene
sequences (MAT1-1-1 and MAT1-2) and the resulting tree topologies were
in accordance with that of the multigene analysis. A bibliographic
review of the proposed links between Ramularia spp. and their purported
Mycosphaerella sexual morphs is also presented, confirming six
connections in Ramularia. In spite of more than 10 000 species having
been described in Mycosphaerella, the majority are shown to belong to
other genera, suggesting that the taxa identified as Mycosphaerella in
much of the plant pathology literature needs to be revisited.
